I'm well aware they are the same person. None of the comments I've seen are targeting (jokingly or otherwise) anyone except Riot. Even in his responses to Apex he is not hurting anyone nor even being particularly offensive even if you are taking him seriously. If there is a specific comment you think is a problem then report it, I don't have time to read everything 100%, especially troll threads, but I read what I could and none of it stood out to me as a a problem.

It would take a lot of games to get banned for behaviour like that, it might be annoying and obnoxious but it's harmless.

As to boards being full of toxicity, there is a different culture here than in game but it isn't toxic, and if you're talking about GD we tend to leave them to themselves unless it gets out of hand. There is certainly frustration, but this is boards, frustration at x thing doesn't hurt anyone, nor does it ruins someone's game experience. 

Past that, we don't censor people who don't like Riot, that would kind of be counterproductive to discussion. Rioters are people, and if they're being targeted specifically we will take action, but Riot is a company and people are perfectly entitled to complain and moan about them all they like.

No, but a mix of all three would be substantially better than what it currently is. They have been saying the'll re-introduce the tribunal for gold only knows how long now.

Toxic people understand ways around the automated system and they continually abuse it. If you had a mixture of all three, automated, human and heavy bans being inforced by Riot support staff it would stop a lot of the not so obvious rubbish that happens. Eg, the guy who sits in the jungle taunting whilst enemy team takes the nexus, or the guy who simply runs is up mid lane trying to 1v5 40 minutes into the game. Or the guy who does nothing but farm for 40 minutes long and does <1k damage to enemy champs. It's this type of rubbish that is killing the game more so than little Johnny who tells me in chat what he supposedly done to my mother last night.

Sure you'd still get a small minority who would abuse the system, but when people know their cases could possibly be reviewed by real individuals who can make common sense judgements it might persuade them to stop or simply not do it.

No, the system only works when banning the obvious. So that's toxic players who verbally abuse people in chat, the people who buy 5 boots and run it up mid going 0-15 within the first 20 minutes and the afkers. How can the system possibly determine that the guy in my last game simply wasn't bad and accidentally ran it up mid lane thinking he could 1v1 a noc? It can't possibly! There is absolutely no way at all it can determine this.

The rest of the people who throw games, intent feed whilst not making it blatantly obvious get away with it without punishment. That's what people are frustrated and pissed off about. But what else do you expect when you have a completely automated system?

Fk even if Riot introduced something like CS:GO where actual players can vote whilst watching the gameplay would be better than this automated garbage.

If you can't afford staff or there are too many reports to handle give it over to the community who would happily do it for you and offer them some small incentive.

But like I said, Riot don't give a shit as long as you're buying RP.

There was a thing called Tribunal, which was essentially what you're talking about there. Though it was removed a long while ago on the basis that the information we used to be able to access wasn't enough to make full judgements (and it was true, as all we had was just chat logs on the Tribunal).

I believe they've said that Tribunal is coming back, and if they are indeed sticking to their words it would be natural to assume that they're trying to rebuild the system with inclusion of in-depth match history information like what we have in our clients but more detailed. And if that's so, it will take a while (though I'll agree that it's indeed taking too long).

Also, since you've seen CS:GO, you should know that the community is also toxic as fk, though on a tiny bit smaller scale thanks to the fact it's buy-to-play but that's not saying much. Similarly, so were the League, where the community was already known to be a toxic hell-hole way before the removal of Tribunal. As such the lesson to learn here is that player-driven judicial system would NOT suddenly make everybody fine, cool and dandy, and we need something else to keep people in line. What would it be? Well that's not my job to work it out, though I could at least see that most devs are trying one way or the other, which also include Riot.

Also, only small offences are given to the automated system to sort out. Big and severe offences/repeat-offences as far as I know, are manually reviewed and pardoned/punished based on human inputs.

How does the system detect that this guy literally just threw the game for no apparent reason other than his own stupidity? IT CAN'T!

An automated system will NEVER work when there are so many variables. You need human interaction in this case to clearly see he intently ran it up mid lane and died on purpose and then made a salty comment losing us the game.

This game is pathetic, the reporting system is pathetic and Riot's attitude towards it is pathetic.

And to all those who say the game is over blah blah, I'm sorry but I don't enjoy spending upwards of 50 minutes trying to win and climb only for some 12yr old to throw a game for no reason at all. It's frustrating and NOT enjoyable. If you're going to treat the game as casual, adopt an intent feeders attitude and not punish those who ruin ranked for others then simply remove it. Everyone plays normals and be done with it.

Note: The current automated system do take in in-game data into account when making decision on whether or not a reported player is indeed guilty. And considering that say our match history on the client could be precise enough to pin-point the sequence of someone's build order and where exactly a teamfight/kill/death happens on the map, there is no reason to assume that the system won't look at those when they're reviewing the reports as well.

But really, the community can't always maintain 2 contradictory opinions at the same time. On one hand you have peeps who complain about system being way too harsh that it hands out bans over every little things, while on the other side sits you, who complain about the very same system saying that doesn't do jack shit.

Which is it?

The answer is obviously very simple, it works, maybe not to the best of its effectiveness, but it does work.

Report system does work to a certain extent, it's just that most players tend to just rage-leave the end-game chat once the torment (be it a game of troll, int feed or whatever) has ended instead of reporting them first before leaving and thus enabling the trolls to roam free as a result of that.

If a player is constantly reported everywhere they go, it is pretty much guaranteed that they will be banned purely on that basis. So yeah, we should use the system more often to its full effectiveness, and obviously not outright abusing it either.
